Question: What position did Margaret Thatcher hold in the cabinet in 1970?
RightAnswer: Secretary of State for Education and Science
Explanation: She was elected as a Conservative MP in 1959 and became a cabinet minister in 1970 as the Secretary of State for Education and Science.

Question: In which year did Margaret Thatcher become Leader of the Conservative Party?
Explanation: In 1975 Margaret Thatcher was elected as Leader of the Conservative Party and so became Leader of the Opposition.

Question: When did Margaret Thatcher become the first woman Prime Minister of the UK?
Explanation: Following the Conservative victory in the General Election in 1979, Margaret Thatcher became the first woman Prime Minister of the UK.

Question: Which US President did Margaret Thatcher work closely with?
Explanation: Margaret Thatcher worked closely with the United States President, Ronald Reagan, and was one of the first Western leaders to recognise and welcome the changes in the leadership of the Soviet Union which eventually led to the end of the Cold War.

Question: For how long did Margaret Thatcher serve as Prime Minister?
Explanation: Margaret Thatcher was Britain's first woman Prime Minister and led the Conservative government from 1979 to 1990. She was the longestserving Prime Minister of the 20th century, remaining in Office until 1990.

Question: Which country invaded the Falkland Islands in 1982?
Explanation: In 1982, Argentina invaded the Falkland Islands, a British overseas territory in the South Atlantic. A naval taskforce was sent from the UK and military action led to the recovery of the islands.

Question: Who succeeded Margaret Thatcher as Prime Minister?
Explanation: John Major was Prime Minister after Mrs Thatcher, and helped establish the Northern Ireland peace process.

Question: Where was Roald Dahl born?
Explanation: Roald Dahl was born in Wales to Norwegian parents. He served in the Royal Air Force during the Second World War. It was during the 1940s that he began to publish books and short stories. His best-known works include Charlie and the Chocolate Factory and George's Marvellous Medicine.

Question: Which of the following is one of Roald Dahl's best-known works?
Explanation: Roald Dahl was born in Wales to Norwegian parents. His best-known works include Charlie and the Chocolate Factory and George's Marvellous Medicine.

Question: In which year was the Labour Party led by Tony Blair elected?
Explanation: In 1997 the Labour Party led by Tony Blair was elected.

Question: In which year was the Good Friday Agreement signed?
Explanation: In Northern Ireland, the Blair government was able to build on the peace process, resulting in the Good Friday Agreement signed in 1998.

Question: When was the Northern Ireland Assembly elected?
Explanation: The Northern Ireland Assembly was elected in 1999 but suspended in 2002.

Question: In which year was the Northern Ireland Assembly reinstated?
Explanation: It was not reinstated until 2007.

Question: Who took over as Prime Minister in 2007?
Explanation: Gordon Brown took over as Prime Minister in 2007.

Question: In which year did Gordon Brown lose the general election?
Explanation: He lost the general election in 2010.

Question: In which year did Iraq invade Kuwait?
Explanation: Throughout the 1990s, Britain played a leading role in coalition forces involved in the liberation of Kuwait, following the Iraqi invasion in 1990, and the conflict in the Former Republic of Yugoslavia.

Question: In which year did British combat troops leave Iraq?
Explanation: British combat troops left Iraq in 2009.

Question: Which two specific operations were British armed forces engaged in since 2000?
Explanation: Since 2000, British armed forces have been engaged in the global fight against international terrorism and against the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, including operations in Afghanistan and Iraq.

Question: In which year did the coalition government in the UK begin?
Explanation: In May 2010, and for the first time in the UK since February 1974, no political party won an overall majority in the General Election. There was a coalition government from 2010 to 2015.

Question: Which two parties formed the coalition government in 2010?
Explanation: The Conservative and Liberal Democrat parties formed a coalition and the leader of the Conservative Party, David Cameron, became Prime Minister.

Question: Who became Prime Minister in the 2010 coalition government?
Explanation: The Conservative and Liberal Democrat parties formed a coalition and the leader of the Conservative Party, David Cameron, became Prime Minister.

Question: How many prime ministers served during the Conservative Government from 2015 to 2024?
Explanation: The Conservative Government, which governed the United Kingdom from 2015 to 2024, saw multiple prime ministers, including David Cameron, Theresa May, Boris Johnson, Liz Truss, and Rishi Sunak.

Question: In which year did the EU membership referendum (Brexit) take place?
Explanation: During this period, significant events included the 2016 EU membership referendum (Brexit), leadership changes, and handling of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Question: Who called for a general election on July 4, 2024?
Explanation: Despite reshuffling his cabinet and local election losses, Rishi Sunak has called for a general election on July 4, 2024.

Question: Who led the Labour party to victory in the 2024 general election?
Explanation: The Labour party, lead by Keir Starmer, won the majority in the 2024 general election and formed the government.

Question: When did Britain become permanently separated from the continent by the Channel?
Explanation: Britain only became permanently separated from the continent by the Channel about 10,000 years ago.

Question: Approximately how long ago did the first farmers arrive in Britain?
Explanation: The first farmers arrived in Britain about 6,000 years ago.

Question: Where did the ancestors of the first farmers in Britain likely come from?
Explanation: The ancestors of these first farmers probably came from south-east Europe.

Question: In which modern English county is Stonehenge located?
Explanation: One of these monuments, Stonehenge, still stands in what is now the English county of Wiltshire.

Question: What is Skara Brae?
RightAnswer: The best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe
Explanation: Skara Brae on Orkney, off the north coast of Scotland, is the best preserved prehistoric village in northern Europe, and has helped archaeologists to understand more about how people lived near the end of the Stone Age.

Question: How long ago did people learn to make bronze?
Explanation: Around 4,000 years ago, people learned to make bronze. We call this period the Bronze Age.

Question: What type of houses did people live in during the Bronze Age?
Explanation: People lived in roundhouses and buried their dead in tombs called round barrows.

Question: What were the tombs of the Bronze Age called?
Explanation: People lived in roundhouses and buried their dead in tombs called round barrows.

Question: What age followed the Bronze Age?
Explanation: The Bronze Age was followed by the Iron Age, when people learned how to make weapons and tools out of iron.

Question: What is the name of the impressive hill fort in Dorset?
Explanation: A very impressive hill fort can still be seen today at Maiden Castle, in the English county of Dorset.

Question: What language family did the Iron Age people in Britain speak?
Explanation: The language they spoke was part of the Celtic language family. Similar languages were spoken across Europe in the Iron Age, and related languages are still spoken today in some parts of Wales, Scotland and Ireland.

Question: What significant development in British history occurred during the Iron Age?
RightAnswer: The first coins were minted in Britain
WrongAnswers: The first written language was developed
Explanation: They made the first coins to be minted in Britain, some inscribed with the names of Iron Age kings. This marks the beginnings of British history.

Question: In which year did Julius Caesar lead a Roman invasion of Britain?
Explanation: Julius Caesar led a Roman invasion of Britain in 55 BC. This was unsuccessful and for nearly 100 years Britain remained separate from the Roman Empire.

Question: Who led the successful Roman invasion of Britain in AD 43?
Explanation: In AD 43 the Emperor Claudius led the Roman army in a new invasion. This time, there was resistance from some of the British tribes but the Romans were successful in occupying almost all of Britain.

Question: Which tribal leader fought against the Romans in eastern England?
Explanation: One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans was Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England. She is still remembered today and there is a statue of her on Westminster Bridge in London, near the Houses of Parliament.

Question: What did Emperor Hadrian build to keep out the Picts?
RightAnswer: A wall in the north of England
Explanation: Areas of what is now Scotland were never conquered by the Romans, and the Emperor Hadrian built a wall in the north of England to keep out the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people).

Question: Which forts along Hadrian's Wall can still be seen today?
Explanation: Parts of Hadrian's Wall, including the forts of Housesteads and Vindolanda, can still be seen. It is a popular area for walkers and is a UNESCO (United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization) World Heritage Site.

Question: How long did the Romans remain in Britain?
Explanation: The Romans remained in Britain for 400 years. They built roads and public buildings, created a structure of law, and introduced new plants and animals.

Question: When did the first Christian communities begin to appear in Britain?
Explanation: It was during the 3rd and 4th centuries AD that the first Christian communities began to appear in Britain.

Question: In which year did the Roman army leave Britain?
Explanation: The Roman army left Britain in AD 410 to defend other parts of the Roman Empire and never returned.

Question: Which tribes invaded Britain after the Roman army left?
RightAnswer: The Jutes, the Angles and the Saxons
WrongAnswers: The Normans, the Vikings and the Celts
The Picts, the Scots and the Britons
The Franks, the Goths and the Vandals
Explanation: Britain was again invaded by tribes from northern Europe: the Jutes, the Angles and the Saxons.

Question: By approximately which year were Anglo-Saxon kingdoms established in Britain?
Explanation: Battles were fought against these invaders but, by about AD 600, Anglo-Saxon kingdoms were established in Britain.

Question: Where was the burial place of one of the Anglo-Saxon kings?
Explanation: The burial place of one of the kings was at Sutton Hoo in modern Suffolk.

Question: Who was the most famous Irish missionary who became the patron saint of Ireland?
Explanation: The most famous of these were St Patrick and St Columba. St Patrick became the patron saint of Ireland.

Question: Where did St Columba found a monastery?
Explanation: St Columba founded a monastery on the island of Iona, off the coast of what is now Scotland.

Question: Who led the missionaries from Rome to spread Christianity in the south of Britain?
Explanation: St Augustine led missionaries from Rome, who spread Christianity in the south. St Augustine became the first Archbishop of Canterbury.

Question: In which year did the Vikings first visit Britain to raid coastal towns?
Explanation: The Vikings came from Denmark and Norway. They first visited Britain in AD 789 to raid coastal towns and take away goods and slaves.

Question: Which Anglo-Saxon king united the kingdoms and defeated the Vikings?
Explanation: The Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England united under King Alfred the Great, who defeated the Vikings.

Question: What was the area in England where many Viking settlers stayed called?
Explanation: Many of the Viking invaders stayed in Britain, especially in the east and north of England, in an area known as the Danelaw (many places names there, such as Grimsby and Scunthorpe, come from the Viking languages).

Question: Who was the first Danish king to rule England?
Explanation: Anglo-Saxon kings continued to rule what is now England, except for a short period when there were Danish kings. The first of these was Cnut, also called Canute.

Question: Which king united the people in the north under the threat of Viking attacks?
Explanation: In the north, the threat of attack by Vikings had encouraged the people to unite under one king, Kenneth MacAlpin. The term Scotland began to be used to describe that country.

Question: Who led the invasion of England in 1066?
Explanation: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings.

Question: Where was the Battle of Hastings fought?
Explanation: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings.

Question: What is the name of the embroidery that commemorates the Battle of Hastings?
Explanation: The battle is commemorated in a great piece of embroidery, known as the Bayeux Tapestry, which can still be seen in France today.

Question: What was the last successful foreign invasion of England?
Explanation: The Norman Conquest was the last successful foreign invasion of England and led to many changes in government and social structures in England.

Question: What language influenced the development of the English language after the Norman Conquest?
Explanation: Norman French, the language of the new ruling class, influenced the development of the English language as we know it today.

Question: What was the name of the comprehensive survey of England ordered by William the Conqueror?
Explanation: William sent people all over England to draw up lists of all the towns and villages. The people who lived there, who owned the land and what animals they owned were also listed. This was called the Domesday Book.

Question: Until what year is the period after the Norman Conquest called the Middle Ages?
Explanation: The period after the Norman Conquest up until about 1485 is called the Middle Ages (or the medieval period).

Question: In which year did King Edward I of England introduce the Statute of Rhuddlan?
Explanation: In 1284 King Edward I of England introduced the Statute of Rhuddlan, which annexed Wales to the Crown of England.

Question: Which castles were built to maintain English power in Wales?
Explanation: Huge castles, including Conwy and Caernarvon, were built to maintain this power.

Question: Who led the Scottish to victory against the English at the Battle of Bannockburn?
Explanation: In 1314 the Scottish, led by Robert the Bruce, defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn, and Scotland remained unconquered by the English.

Question: What was the area around Dublin ruled by the English in Ireland called?
Explanation: By 1200, the English ruled an area of Ireland known as the Pale, around Dublin.

Question: What was the name of the war fought between England and France during the Middle Ages?
Explanation: English kings also fought a long war with France, called the Hundred Years War (even though it actually lasted 116 years).

Question: How long did the Hundred Years War actually last?
Explanation: English kings also fought a long war with France, called the Hundred Years War (even though it actually lasted 116 years).

Question: In which year did the Battle of Agincourt take place?
Explanation: One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, where King Henry V's vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French.

Question: Which English king led the vastly outnumbered English army to victory at the Battle of Agincourt?
Explanation: One of the most famous battles of the Hundred Years War was the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, where King Henry V's vastly outnumbered English army defeated the French.

Question: In which decade did the English leave France after the Hundred Years War?
Explanation: The English left France in the 1450s.

Question: What system of land ownership did the Normans use?
Explanation: The Normans used a system of land ownership known as feudalism.

Question: What did the king give to his lords in return for help in war?
Explanation: The king gave land to his lords in return for help in war.

Question: What were most peasants called in the feudal system?
Explanation: Some peasants had their own land but most were serfs.

Question: In the north of Scotland and Ireland, who owned the land?
Explanation: In the north of Scotland and Ireland, land was owned by members of the 'clans' (prominent families).

Question: Where else did the feudal system develop besides England?
Explanation: The same system developed in southern Scotland.

Question: In which year did the Black Death arrive in Britain?
Explanation: In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain. This was known as the Black Death.

Question: What proportion of England's population died due to the Black Death?
Explanation: One third of the population of England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales.

Question: What new social class emerged following the Black Death?
Explanation: New social classes appeared, including owners of large areas of land (later called the gentry), and people left the countryside to live in the towns.

Question: What economic effect did the Black Death have on peasants?
RightAnswer: They began to demand higher wages
WrongAnswers: They were forced to work longer hours
They had to pay higher taxes
Explanation: There were labour shortages and peasants began to demand higher wages.

Question: What happened to the area controlled by the English in Ireland after the Black Death?
Explanation: In Ireland, the Black Death killed many in the Pale and, for a time, the area controlled by the English became smaller.

Question: In which year was King John forced by his noblemen to agree to a number of demands?
Explanation: There were few formal limits to the king's power until 1215. In that year (1215), King John was forced by his noblemen to agree to a number of demands.

Question: What was the name of the charter of rights agreed upon by King John and his noblemen?
Explanation: The result was a charter of rights called the Magna Carta (which means the Great Charter).

Question: Which two Houses were established in the English Parliament?
RightAnswer: House of Lords and House of Commons
WrongAnswers: House of Nobles and House of Clergy
House of Commons and House of Bishops
House of Lords and House of Knights
Explanation: The nobility, great landowners and bishops sat in the House of Lords. Knights, who were usually smaller landowners, and wealthy people from towns and cities were elected to sit in the House of Commons.

Question: How many Houses did the Scottish Parliament have?
Explanation: A similar Parliament developed in Scotland. It had three Houses, called Estates: the lords, the commons and the clergy.

Question: What were the three Estates in the Scottish Parliament?
RightAnswer: The lords, the commons and the clergy
WrongAnswers: The nobility, the knights and the bishops
The landowners, the merchants and the peasants
The king, the nobles and the commoners
Explanation: A similar Parliament developed in Scotland. It had three Houses, called Estates: the lords, the commons and the clergy.

Question: How did judges develop 'common law' in England?
RightAnswer: By a process of precedence and tradition
Explanation: In England, judges developed 'common law' by a process of precedence (that is, following previous decisions) and tradition.

Question: How did the legal system develop differently in Scotland?
WrongAnswers: Laws were decided by the king
Explanation: In Scotland, the legal system developed slightly differently and laws were 'codified' (that is, written down).

Question: What two languages combined to form the English language after the Norman Conquest?
Explanation: After the Norman Conquest, the king and his noblemen had spoken Norman French and the peasants had continued to speak Anglo-Saxon. Gradually these two languages combined to become one English language.

Question: Who wrote The Canterbury Tales?
Explanation: In the years leading up to 1400, Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series of poems in English about a group of people going to Canterbury on a pilgrimage. The people decided to tell each other stories on the journey, and the poems describe the travellers and some of the stories they told. This collection of poems is called The Canterbury Tales.

Question: Who was the first person to print books using a printing press in England?
Explanation: It was one of the first books to be printed by William Caxton, the first person in England to print books using a printing press.

Question: Which language developed in Scotland alongside Gaelic?
Explanation: In Scotland, many people continued to speak Gaelic and the Scots language also developed.

Question: Who wrote The Bruce about the Battle of Bannockburn?
Explanation: A number of poets began to write in the Scots language. One example is John Barbour, who wrote The Bruce about the Battle of Bannockburn.

Question: Which cathedral is famous for its stained glass windows?
Explanation: Several of the cathedrals had windows of stained glass, telling stories about the Bible and Christian saints. The glass in York Minster is a famous example.

Question: What became a very important export from England during the Middle Ages?
Explanation: During this period, England was an important trading nation. English wool became a very important export.

Question: In which year did the Wars of the Roses begin?
Explanation: In 1455, a civil war was begun to decide who should be king of England.

Question: What was the symbol of the House of Lancaster?
Explanation: This war was called the Wars of the Roses, because the symbol of Lancaster was a red rose and the symbol of York was a white rose.

Question: Which battle marked the end of the Wars of the Roses?
Explanation: The war ended with the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485.

Question: Who became king after the Battle of Bosworth Field?
Explanation: King Richard III of the House of York was killed in the battle and Henry Tudor, the leader of the House of Lancaster, became King Henry VII.

Question: What was the symbol of the House of Tudor?
RightAnswer: A red rose with a white rose inside it
WrongAnswers: A white rose with a red rose inside it
Explanation: The symbol of the House of Tudor was a red rose with a white rose inside it as a sign that the Houses of York and Lancaster were now allies.

Question: What did Henry VII do to secure his position as king?
RightAnswer: Strengthened central administration and reduced the power of nobles
WrongAnswers: Married into the House of York
Explanation: He deliberately strengthened the central administration of England and reduced the power of the nobles.

Question: How many times did Henry VIII marry?
Explanation: Henry VIII was most famous for breaking away from the Church of Rome and marrying six times.

Question: Which of Henry VIII's wives was Spanish?
Explanation: Catherine of Aragon was a Spanish princess. She and Henry had a number of children but only one, Mary, survived.

Question: Which of Henry VIII's wives gave birth to Elizabeth?
Explanation: Anne Boleyn was English. She and Henry had one daughter, Elizabeth.

Question: Which wife gave Henry VIII the son he wanted?
Explanation: Henry married Jane after Anne's execution. She gave Henry the son he wanted, Edward, but she died shortly after the birth.

Question: Which of Henry VIII's wives was German?
Explanation: Anne of Cleves was a German princess. Henry married her for political reasons but divorced her soon after.

Question: Who was the cousin of Anne Boleyn that Henry VIII married?
Explanation: Catherine Howard was a cousin of Anne Boleyn. She was also accused of taking lovers and executed.

Question: Which of Henry VIII's wives was a widow before marrying him?
Explanation: Catherine Parr was a widow who married Henry late in his life. She survived him and married again but died soon after.

Question: Why did Henry VIII establish the Church of England?
Explanation: To divorce his first wife, Henry needed the approval of the Pope. When the Pope refused, Henry established the Church of England.

Question: What was the Reformation a movement against?
RightAnswer: The authority of the Pope and the ideas and practices of the Roman Catholic Church
WrongAnswers: The use of English in churches
Explanation: This was a movement against the authority of the Pope and the ideas and practices of the Roman Catholic Church.

Question: In which language did Protestants read the Bible?
Explanation: They read the Bible in their own languages instead of in Latin.

Question: What act formally united Wales with England during Henry VIII's reign?
RightAnswer: Act for the Government of Wales
Explanation: During the reign of Henry VIII, Wales became formally united with England by the Act for the Government of Wales.

Question: What was created during Edward VI's reign to be used in the Church of England?
Explanation: During his reign, the Book of Common Prayer was written to be used in the Church of England.

Question: Who was known as 'Bloody Mary'?
Explanation: Mary was a devout Catholic and persecuted Protestants (for this reason, she became known as 'Bloody Mary').

Question: Who succeeded Mary as monarch?
Explanation: Mary also died after a short reign and the next monarch was her half-sister, Elizabeth, the daughter of Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn.

Question: What did Queen Elizabeth I re-establish as the official Church in England?
Explanation: She re-established the Church of England as the official Church in England.

Question: In which year did the English defeat the Spanish Armada?
Explanation: Elizabeth became one of the most popular monarchs in English history, particularly after 1588, when the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism.

Question: In which year did the Scottish Parliament abolish the authority of the Pope in Scotland?
Explanation: In 1560, the predominantly Protestant Scottish Parliament abolished the authority of the Pope in Scotland and Roman Catholic religious services became illegal.

Question: Who was one of the commanders in the defeat of the Spanish Armada and a founder of England's naval tradition?
Explanation: Sir Francis Drake, one of the commanders in the defeat of the Spanish Armada, was one of the founders of England's naval tradition.

Question: What was the name of Sir Francis Drake's ship that circumnavigated the world?
Explanation: His ship, the Golden Hind, was one of the first to sail right around ('circumnavigate') the world.

Question: Who was a notable playwright and poet of the Elizabethan period?
Explanation: The Elizabethan period is also remembered for the richness of its poetry and drama, especially the plays and poems of William Shakespeare.

Question: How old was Mary Stuart when she became queen of Scotland?
Explanation: She was only a week old when her father died and she became queen.

Question: Where did Mary Stuart spend much of her childhood?
Explanation: Much of her childhood was spent in France.

Question: To whom did Mary Stuart give her throne when she fled to England?
Explanation: She gave her throne to her Protestant son, James VI of Scotland.

Question: How long was Mary Stuart kept as a prisoner by Elizabeth I?
Explanation: Elizabeth suspected Mary of wanting to take over the English throne, and kept her a prisoner for 20 years.

Question: What was Mary Stuart accused of that led to her execution?
Explanation: Mary was eventually executed, accused of plotting against Elizabeth I.

Question: Where was William Shakespeare born?
Explanation: Shakespeare was born in Stratford-upon-Avon, England.

Question: From which play is the quote 'To be or not to be' taken?
Explanation: Lines from his plays and poems which are often still quoted include: Once more unto the breach (Henry V). To be or not to be (Hamlet). A rose by any other name (Romeo and Juliet).

Question: Which Shakespeare play contains the line 'All the world's a stage'?
Explanation: Lines from his plays and poems which are often still quoted include: Once more unto the breach (Henry V). To be or not to be (Hamlet). A rose by any other name (Romeo and Juliet). All the world's a stage (As You Like It).

Question: Which theatre in London is a modern copy of the theatres where Shakespeare's plays were first performed?
Explanation: The Globe Theatre in London is a modern copy of the theatres in which his plays were first performed.

Question: Who became the heir to Elizabeth I's throne?
Explanation: When she died in 1603 her heir was her cousin James VI of Scotland. He became King James I of England, Wales and Ireland but Scotland remained a separate country.

Question: What was King James I's title in Scotland?
Explanation: When she died in 1603 her heir was her cousin James VI of Scotland. He became King James I of England, Wales and Ireland but Scotland remained a separate country.

Question: What major achievement occurred during King James' reign?
RightAnswer: A new translation of the Bible into English
WrongAnswers: The unification of England and Scotland
The defeat of the Spanish Armada
The establishment of the Church of England
Explanation: One achievement of King James' reign was a new translation of the Bible into English. This translation is known as the 'King James Version' or the 'Authorised Version'.

Question: What are the two names by which the new Bible translation (written during King James' reign) is known?
RightAnswer: King James Version and Authorised Version
WrongAnswers: New English Bible and Revised Standard Version
Good News Bible and New International Version
Jerusalem Bible and New American Bible
Explanation: This translation is known as the 'King James Version' or the 'Authorised Version'.

Question: Which English monarch first took the title 'King of Ireland'?
Explanation: Henry VIII took the title 'King of Ireland'.

Question: Who were expected to follow the instructions of the Lord Lieutenants in Dublin?
Explanation: Henry VIII took the title 'King of Ireland'. English laws were introduced and local leaders were expected to follow the instructions of the Lord Lieutenants in Dublin.

Question: During which monarchs' reigns were there rebellions against Protestant rule in Ireland?
Explanation: During the reigns of Elizabeth I and James I, many people in Ireland opposed rule by the Protestant government in England. There were a number of rebellions.

Question: In which province of Ireland did the English government (Elizabeth I and James I) encourage Scottish and English Protestants to settle?
Explanation: During the reigns of Elizabeth I and James I, many people in Ireland opposed rule by the Protestant government in England. There were a number of rebellions. The English government encouraged Scottish and English Protestants to settle in Ulster, the northern province of Ireland, taking over the land from Catholic landholders.

Question: What were the settlements of Scottish and English Protestants in Ireland known as (during Elizabeth I and James I reigns)?
Explanation: During the reigns of Elizabeth I and James I, many people in Ireland opposed rule by the Protestant government in England. There were a number of rebellions. The English government encouraged Scottish and English Protestants to settle in Ulster, the northern province of Ireland, taking over the land from Catholic landholders. These settlements were known as plantations.

Question: From which part of Scotland did many of the new settlers in Ulster come?
Explanation: During the reigns of Elizabeth I and James I, many people in Ireland opposed rule by the Protestant government in England. There were a number of rebellions. The English government encouraged Scottish and English Protestants to settle in Ulster, the northern province of Ireland, taking over the land from Catholic landholders. Many of the new settlers came from south-west Scotland and other land was given to companies based in London.

Question: How many years did Charles I rule without Parliament?
Explanation: For 11 years, he found ways in which to raise money without Parliament's approval but eventually trouble in Scotland meant that he had to recall Parliament.

Question: In which year did Charles I recall Parliament to ask for funds?
Explanation: In 1640, he recalled Parliament to ask it for funds.

Question: What were the supporters of Parliament called during the Civil War?
Explanation: The country split into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).

Question: In which year did the Civil War between the king and Parliament begin?
Explanation: Civil war between the king and Parliament could not now be avoided and began in 1642.

Question: What did Charles I try to impose on the Presbyterian Church in Scotland?
Explanation: Charles I wanted the worship of the Church of England to include more ceremony and introduced a revised Prayer Book. He tried to impose this Prayer Book on the Presbyterian Church in Scotland and this led to serious unrest.

Question: How many parliamentary leaders did Charles I try to arrest in the House of Commons?
Explanation: In response, Charles I entered the House of Commons and tried to arrest five parliamentary leaders, but they had been warned and were not there.

Question: What were the supporters of the king called during the Civil War?
Explanation: The country split into those who supported the king (the Cavaliers) and those who supported Parliament (the Roundheads).

Question: At which battles was the king's army defeated?
Explanation: The king's army was defeated at the Battles of Marston Moor and Naseby.

Question: In which year was Charles I executed?
Explanation: He was still unwilling to reach any agreement with Parliament and in 1649 he was executed.

Question: What was the name of the republic declared after Charles I's execution?
Explanation: England declared itself a republic, called the Commonwealth.

Question: Who was sent to Ireland to establish the authority of the English Parliament?
Explanation: One of its generals, Oliver Cromwell, was sent to Ireland, where the revolt which had begun in 1641 still continued and where there was still a Royalist army. Cromwell was successful in establishing the authority of the English Parliament but did this with such violence that even today Cromwell remains a controversial figure in Ireland.

Question: Where did Charles II famously hide during his escape?
Explanation: Charles II escaped from Worcester, famously hiding in an oak tree on one occasion, and eventually fled to Europe.

Question: What title was Oliver Cromwell given as leader of the new republic?
Explanation: He was given the title of Lord Protector and ruled until his death in 1658.

Question: Who became Lord Protector after Oliver Cromwell's death?
Explanation: When Cromwell died, his son, Richard, became Lord Protector in his place but was not able to control the army or the government.

Question: How long had Britain been a republic before people began talking about the need for a king again?
Explanation: Although Britain had been a republic for 11 years, without Oliver Cromwell there was no clear leader or system of government. Many people in the country wanted stability. People began to talk about the need for a king.

Question: In which year was Charles II invited back from exile to become king?
Explanation: In May 1660, Parliament invited Charles II to come back from exile in the Netherlands. He was crowned King Charles II of England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland.

Question: Which country was Charles II exiled in before becoming king?
Explanation: In May 1660, Parliament invited Charles II to come back from exile in the Netherlands.

Question: Which church became the established official Church during Charles II's reign?
Explanation: The Church of England again became the established official Church. Both Roman Catholics and Puritans were kept out of power.

Question: In which year was there a major outbreak of plague in London during Charles II's reign?
Explanation: During Charles II's reign, in 1665, there was a major outbreak of plague in London. Thousands of people died, especially in poorer areas.

Question: Who designed the new St Paul's Cathedral after the Great Fire of London?
Explanation: London was rebuilt with a new St Paul's, which was designed by a famous architect, Sir Christopher Wren.

Question: In which year did the Habeas Corpus Act become law?
Explanation: The Habeas Corpus Act became law in 1679. This was a very important piece of legislation which remains relevant today.

Question: What scientific society was formed during Charles II's reign?
Explanation: During his reign, the Royal Society was formed to promote 'natural knowledge'. This is the oldest surviving scientific society in the world.

Question: Which famous scientist was an early member of the Royal Society?
Explanation: Among its early members were Sir Edmund Halley, who successfully predicted the return of the comet now called Halley's Comet.

Question: Where was Isaac Newton born?
Explanation: Born in Lincolnshire, eastern England, Isaac Newton first became interested in science when he studied at Cambridge University.

Question: What was the title of Isaac Newton's most famous published work?
Explanation: His most famous published work was Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica ('Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy'), which showed how gravity applied to the whole universe.

Question: What did Isaac Newton discover about white light?
RightAnswer: It is made up of the colours of the rainbow
WrongAnswers: It is a single pure color
It is composed of only blue and yellow
Explanation: Newton also discovered that white light is made up of the colours of the rainbow.

Question: Where did Isaac Newton first become interested in science?
Explanation: Born in Lincolnshire, eastern England, Isaac Newton first became interested in science when he studied at Cambridge University.

Question: In which year did Charles II die?
Explanation: Charles II had no legitimate children. He died in 1685 and his brother, James, who was a Roman Catholic, became King James II in England, Wales and Ireland and King James VII of Scotland.

Question: Who became King after Charles II's death?
Explanation: Charles II had no legitimate children. He died in 1685 and his brother, James, who was a Roman Catholic, became King James II in England, Wales and Ireland and King James VII of Scotland.

Question: What was James II's religion?
Explanation: Charles II had no legitimate children. He died in 1685 and his brother, James, who was a Roman Catholic, became King James II in England, Wales and Ireland and King James VII of Scotland.

Question: What did James II allow Roman Catholics to be, which was previously forbidden by an Act of Parliament?
Explanation: James favoured Roman Catholics and allowed them to be army Officers, which an Act of Parliament had forbidden.

Question: What religion were James II's two daughters?
Explanation: However, his heirs were his two daughters, who were both firmly Protestant, and people thought that this meant there would soon be a Protestant monarch again.

Question: Who was James II's elder daughter married to?
Explanation: James II's elder daughter, Mary, was married to her cousin William of Orange, the Protestant ruler of the Netherlands.

Question: In which year did important Protestants in England ask William to invade England?
Explanation: In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William to invade England and proclaim himself king.

Question: What title did William take in England, Wales and Ireland?
Explanation: James fled to France and William took over the throne, becoming William III in England, Wales and Ireland, and William II of Scotland.

Question: Why was this event called the 'Glorious Revolution'?
RightAnswer: There was no fighting in England and it guaranteed the power of Parliament
Explanation: This event was later called the 'Glorious Revolution' because there was no fighting in England and because it guaranteed the power of Parliament, ending the threat of a monarch ruling on his or her own as he or she wished.

Question: Where did James II invade with the help of a French army?
Explanation: James II wanted to regain the throne and invaded Ireland with the help of a French army.

Question: In which battle did William defeat James II in Ireland?
Explanation: William defeated James II at the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland in 1690, an event which is still celebrated by some in Northern Ireland today.

Question: Where was an armed rebellion in support of James quickly defeated?
Explanation: An attempt at an armed rebellion in support of James was quickly defeated at Killiecrankie.

Question: Which Scottish clan was killed for being late in taking the oath to accept William as king?
Explanation: The MacDonalds of Glencoe were late in taking the oath and were all killed.

Question: What were James' supporters known as?
Explanation: James' supporters became known as Jacobites.

Question: What document was read at the coronation of William and Mary?
Explanation: At the coronation of William and Mary, a Declaration of Rights was read. This confirmed that the king would no longer be able to raise taxes or administer justice without agreement from Parliament.

Question: In which year was the Bill of Rights passed?
Explanation: The Bill of Rights (1689) confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king's power.

Question: How often did a new Parliament have to be elected according to the new rules?
Explanation: A new Parliament had to be elected at least every three years (later this became seven years and now it is five years).

Question: What were the two main groups in Parliament called?
Explanation: There were two main groups in Parliament, known as the Whigs and the Tories.

Question: From which year were newspapers allowed to operate without a government licence?
Explanation: From 1695, newspapers were allowed to operate without a government licence.

Question: In which year did the first Jews since the Middle Ages settle in London?
Explanation: The first Jews to come to Britain since the Middle Ages settled in London in 1656.

Question: Who were the Huguenots?
Explanation: Between 1680 and 1720 many refugees called Huguenots came from France. They were Protestants and had been persecuted for their religion.

Question: In which year was the Act of Union agreed?
Explanation: The Act of Union, known as the Treaty of Union in Scotland, was agreed in 1707, creating the Kingdom of Great Britain.

Question: Who became king after Queen Anne died in 1714?
Explanation: When Queen Anne died in 1714, Parliament chose a German, George I, to be the next king, because he was Anne's nearest Protestant relative.

Question: Who was the first person to be called Prime Minister?
Explanation: The most important minister in Parliament became known as the Prime Minister. The first man to be called this was Sir Robert Walpole, who was Prime Minister from 1721 to 1742.

Question: Who attempted to reclaim the throne from George II in 1745?
Explanation: In 1745 there was another attempt to put a Stuart king back on the throne in place of George I's son, George II. Charles Edward Stuart (Bonnie Prince Charlie), the grandson of James II, landed in Scotland.

Question: Where was the decisive battle fought that defeated Charles Edward Stuart's rebellion?
Explanation: Charles initially had some successes but was defeated by George II's army at the Battle of Culloden in 1746.

Question: What year was the Battle of Culloden fought?
Explanation: Charles initially had some successes but was defeated by George II's army at the Battle of Culloden in 1746.

Question: What process began after the Battle of Culloden that involved the destruction of small farms?
Explanation: A process began which became known as the 'Highland Clearances'. Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as 'crofts') to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle.

Question: What were the small farms in Scotland called that were destroyed during the Highland Clearances?
Explanation: Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as 'crofts') to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle.

Question: Where did many Scottish people emigrate to during the early 19th century?
Explanation: Many Scottish people left for North America at this time.

Question: What is Robert Burns known as in Scotland?
Explanation: Known in Scotland as 'The Bard', Robert Burns was a Scottish poet. He wrote in the Scots language, English with some Scottish words, and standard English.

Question: In which languages did Robert Burns write?
RightAnswer: Scots language, English with some Scottish words, and standard English
Explanation: He wrote in the Scots language, English with some Scottish words, and standard English.

Question: What is Robert Burns' best-known work?
Explanation: Known in Scotland as 'The Bard', Robert Burns was a Scottish poet. He wrote in the Scots language, English with some Scottish words, and standard English. Burns' best-known work is probably the song Auld Lang Syne, which is sung by people in the UK and other countries when they are celebrating the New Year (or Hogmanay as it is called in Scotland).

Question: What is the New Year celebration called in Scotland?
Explanation: Burns' best-known work is probably the song Auld Lang Syne, which is sung by people in the UK and other countries when they are celebrating the New Year (or Hogmanay as it is called in Scotland).

Question: In which century did the Enlightenment take place?
Explanation: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This is often called 'the Enlightenment'.

Question: Which Scottish thinker developed influential ideas about economics?
Explanation: Adam Smith developed ideas about economics which are still referred to today.

Question: Whose ideas about human nature continue to influence philosophers?
Explanation: David Hume's ideas about human nature continue to influence philosophers.

Question: What scientific work by James Watt helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution?
Explanation: Scientific discoveries, such as James Watt's work on steam power, helped the progress of the Industrial Revolution.

Question: What was one of the most important principles of the Enlightenment?
RightAnswer: Everyone should have the right to their own political and religious beliefs
WrongAnswers: The state should dictate political and religious beliefs
Only the educated should have political rights
Explanation: One of the most important principles of the Enlightenment was that everyone should have the right to their own political and religious beliefs and that the state should not try to dictate to them. This continues to be an important principle in the UK today.

Question: What was the biggest source of employment in Britain before the 18th century?
Explanation: Before the 18th century, agriculture was the biggest source of employment in Britain.

Question: In which centuries did the Industrial Revolution occur in Britain?
Explanation: The Industrial Revolution was the rapid development of industry in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries.

Question: What process led to the development of the shipbuilding industry and railways?
Explanation: The development of the Bessemer process for the mass production of steel led to the development of the shipbuilding industry and the railways.

Question: Who mapped the coast of Australia?
Explanation: Captain James Cook mapped the coast of Australia and a few colonies were established there.

Question: Which company gained control of large parts of India?
Explanation: Britain gained control over Canada, and the East India Company, originally set up to trade, gained control of large parts of India.

Question: What were two products imported from North America and the West Indies?
Explanation: Sugar and tobacco came from North America and the West Indies.

Question: Which country was Britain's main rival in overseas trade and expansion?
Explanation: Trading and settlements overseas sometimes brought Britain into conflict with other countries, particularly France, which was expanding and trading in a similar way in many of the same areas of the world.

Question: What was Richard Arkwright's original profession?
Explanation: Born in 1732, Arkwright originally trained and worked as a barber. He was able to dye hair and make wigs. When wigs became less popular, he started to work in textiles. He improved the original carding machine. Carding is the process of preparing fibres for spinning into yarn and fabric. He also developed horse-driven spinning mills that used only one machine. This increased the efficiency of production. Later, he used the steam engine to power machinery. Arkwright is particularly remembered for the efficient and profitable way that he ran his factories.

Question: What power source did Arkwright later use to power machinery?
Explanation: Born in 1732, Arkwright originally trained and worked as a barber. He was able to dye hair and make wigs. When wigs became less popular, he started to work in textiles. He improved the original carding machine. Carding is the process of preparing fibres for spinning into yarn and fabric. He also developed horse-driven spinning mills that used only one machine. This increased the efficiency of production. Later, he used the steam engine to power machinery. Arkwright is particularly remembered for the efficient and profitable way that he ran his factories.

Question: Where did Sake Dean Mahomet grow up?
Explanation: Mahomet grew up in the Bengal region of India.

Question: In which year did Mahomet open the Hindoostane Coffee House?
Explanation: Mahomet grew up in the Bengal region of India. He served in the Bengal army and came to Britain, then he moved to Ireland and eloped with an Irish girl called Jane Daly, returning to England at the turn of the century. In 1810 he opened the Hindoostane Coffee House in George Street, London. It was the first curry house to open in Britain.

Question: What was significant about the Hindoostane Coffee House?
RightAnswer: It was the first curry house to open in Britain
WrongAnswers: It was the first coffee house in London
It was the largest restaurant in Britain
It was the first Indian-owned business in London
Explanation: In 1810 he opened the Hindoostane Coffee House in George Street, London. It was the first curry house to open in Britain.

Question: What Indian practice did Mahomet and his wife introduce to Britain?
Explanation: In 1810 Mahomet opened the Hindoostane Coffee House in George Street, London. It was the first curry house to open in Britain. Mahomet and his wife also introduced 'shampooing', the Indian art of head massage, to Britain.

Question: By which century was the slave trade a fully established overseas industry?
Explanation: While slavery was illegal within Britain itself, by the 18th century it was a fully established overseas industry, dominated by Britain and the American colonies.

Question: From which region did slaves primarily come?
Explanation: Slaves came primarily from West Africa.

Question: Who set up the first formal anti-slavery groups in the late 1700s?
Explanation: The first formal anti-slavery groups were set up by the Quakers in the late 1700s, and they petitioned Parliament to ban the practice.

Question: Which prominent member of Parliament played an important role in changing the law regarding slavery?
Explanation: William Wilberforce, an evangelical Christian and a member of Parliament, also played an important part in changing the law.

Question: In which year did it become illegal to trade slaves in British ships or from British ports?
Explanation: In 1807, it became illegal to trade slaves in British ships or from British ports, and in 1833 the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.

Question: What act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire in 1833?
Explanation: In 1807, it became illegal to trade slaves in British ships or from British ports, and in 1833 the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.

Question: How many Indian and Chinese workers were employed to replace the freed slaves after 1833?
Explanation: After 1833, 2 million Indian and Chinese workers were employed to replace the freed slaves.

Question: By which decade were there substantial British colonies in North America?
Explanation: By the 1760s, there were substantial British colonies in North America.

Question: What was the colonists' slogan regarding taxation?
Explanation: The colonists saw this as an attack on their freedom and said there should be 'no taxation without representation' in the British Parliament.

Question: In which year did 13 American colonies declare their independence?
Explanation: In 1776, 13 American colonies declared their independence, stating that people had a right to establish their own governments.

Question: In which year did Britain recognize the colonies' independence?
Explanation: The colonists eventually defeated the British army and Britain recognised the colonies' independence in 1783.

Question: In which year did the French Revolution occur?
Explanation: In 1789, there was a revolution in France and the new French government soon declared war on Britain.

Question: Who became Emperor of France and continued the war with Britain?
Explanation: Napoleon, who became Emperor of France, continued the war.

Question: In which year did the Battle of Trafalgar take place?
Explanation: Britain's navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805.

Question: Who was in charge of the British fleet at the Battle of Trafalgar?
Explanation: Admiral Nelson was in charge of the British fleet at Trafalgar and was killed in the battle.

Question: Where can Admiral Nelson's ship, HMS Victory, be visited?
Explanation: His ship, HMS Victory, can be visited in Portsmouth.

Question: In which year did the French Wars end?
Explanation: In 1815, the French Wars ended with the defeat of the Emperor Napoleon by the Duke of Wellington at the Battle of Waterloo.

Question: Who defeated Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo?
Explanation: In 1815, the French Wars ended with the defeat of the Emperor Napoleon by the Duke of Wellington at the Battle of Waterloo.

Question: What was the Duke of Wellington's nickname?
Explanation: In 1815, the French Wars ended with the defeat of the Emperor Napoleon by the Duke of Wellington at the Battle of Waterloo. Wellington was known as the Iron Duke and later became Prime Minister.

Question: In which year did Ireland become unified with England, Scotland and Wales?
Explanation: In 1801, Ireland became unified with England, Scotland and Wales after the Act of Union of 1800. This created the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.

Question: What is the Union Flag often called?
Explanation: One symbol of this union between England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland was a new version of the official flag, the Union Flag. This is often called the Union Jack.

Question: Which three crosses are combined in the Union Flag?
RightAnswer: The crosses of St George, St Andrew, and St Patrick
WrongAnswers: The crosses of St David, St Andrew, and St Patrick
The crosses of St George, St David, and St Patrick
The crosses of St George, St Andrew, and St David
Explanation: The flag combined crosses associated with England, Scotland and Ireland. The Union Flag consists of three crosses: The cross of St George, patron saint of England, is a red cross on a white ground. The cross of St Andrew, patron saint of Scotland, is a diagonal white cross on a blue ground. The cross of St Patrick, patron saint of Ireland, is a diagonal red cross on a white ground.

Question: What does the official Welsh flag show?

It runs from Paddington Station in London to the south west of England, the West Midlands and Wales. Many of Brunel's bridges are still in use today.

Question: In which year did the Crimean War begin?

Question: Until which year did a woman's earnings, property and money automatically belong to her husband upon marriage?

Question: What is William Beveridge best known for?

Question: How many 'Giant Evils' did the Beveridge Report identify?

Question: Where was Dylan Thomas born?

Question: Why was further immigration encouraged during the 1950s in the UK?
Explanation: During the 1950s, there was still a shortage of labour in the UK. Further immigration was therefore encouraged for economic reasons, and many industries advertised for workers from overseas. For example, centres were set up in the West Indies to recruit people to drive buses. Textile and engineering firms from the north of England and the Midlands sent agents to India and Pakistan to find workers. For about 25 years, people from the West Indies, India, Pakistan and (later) Bangladesh travelled to work and settle in Britain.

Question: Which festival is often called the Festival of Lights and is celebrated by Hindus and Sikhs?

Question: Which composer was the organist at Westminster Abbey and wrote church music, operas, and other pieces?

Question: Which British landmark is a Ferris wheel originally built as part of the UK’s celebration of the new millennium?

Question: Which national park, covering 885 square miles, is the largest in England?

Question: Which day is also called Pancake Day and is observed on the day before Lent begins?

Question: Which British holiday, celebrated on 31 December, is known in Scotland as Hogmanay?

Question: Which day, falling on 11 November, commemorates those who died fighting for the UK and its allies?

Question: Which murder-mystery play by Dame Agatha Christie has been running in the West End since 1952?

Question: Which festival in Wales is an annual cultural festival that includes music, dance, art, and original performances largely in Welsh?

Question: Which festival, known as ‘the Fringe’, is the biggest and most well-known part of the Edinburgh Festival?

Question: Which group of artists in the second half of the 19th century painted detailed pictures on religious or literary themes in bright colours?

Question: Which poem by William Blake begins with the lines, 'Tyger! Tyger! Burning bright; In the forests of the night'?

Question: Which poem by William Wordsworth begins, 'I wander’d lonely as a cloud; That floats on high o’er vales and hills'?

Question: Which attraction in Cornwall, in the south west of England, has biomes that house plants from all over the world?

Question: Who could vote in Britain at the turn of the 19th century?
Explanation: At the turn of the 19th century, Britain was not a democracy as we know it today. Although there were elections to select members of Parliament (MPs), only a small group of people could vote. They were men who were over 21 years of age and who owned a certain amount of property. The franchise (that is, the number of people who had the right to vote) grew over the course of the 19th century and political parties began to involve ordinary men and women as members.

Question: How is the British constitution described?
Explanation: The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as ‘unwritten’. This is mainly because the UK, unlike America or France, has never had a revolution which led permanently to a totally new system of government. Our most important institutions have developed over hundreds of years. Some people believe that there should be a single document, but others believe an unwritten constitution allows for more flexibility and better government.

Question: Who is the head of state in the UK?
Explanation: The monarch is the head of state of the UK. The monarch or head of state for many countries in the Commonwealth. The UK has a constitutional monarchy. This means that the king or queen does not rule the country but appoints the government, which the people have chosen in a democratic election. The monarch invites the leader of the party with the largest number of MPs, or the leader of a coalition between more than one party, to become the Prime Minister. The monarch has regular meetings with the Prime Minister and can advise, warn and encourage, but the decisions on government policies are made by the Prime Minister and cabinet.

Question: What is the system of government in the UK?
Explanation: The system of government in the UK is a parliamentary democracy. The UK is divided into parliamentary constituencies. Voters in each constituency elect their member of Parliament (MP) in a General Election. All of the elected MPs form the House of Commons. Most MPs belong to a political party, and the party with the majority of MPs forms the government. If one party does not get a majority, two parties can join together to form a coalition.

Question: What are peers nominated by the Prime Minister for their lifetime called?
Explanation: Since 1958, the Prime Minister has had the power to nominate peers just for their own lifetime. These are called life peers. They have usually had an important career in politics, business, law or another profession. Life peers are appointed by the monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister. They also include people nominated by the leaders of the other main political parties or by an independent Appointments Commission for non-party peers. Since 1999, hereditary peers have lost the automatic right to attend the House of Lords. They now elect a few of their number to represent them in the House of Lords.

Question: How often are General Elections held in the UK?
Explanation: MPs are elected at a General Election, which is held at least every five years. If an MP dies or resigns, there will be a fresh election, called a byelection, in his or her constituency. The government is usually formed by the party that wins the majority of constituencies. If no party wins a majority, two parties may join together to form a coalition.

Question: In which year did the UK sign the European Convention on Human Rights?
Explanation: British diplomats and lawyers had an important role in drafting the European Convention on Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms. The UK was one of the first countries to sign the Convention in 1950. Some of the principles included in the European Convention on Human Rights are: right to life, prohibition of torture, prohibition of slavery and forced labour, right to liberty and security, right to a fair trial, freedom of thought, conscience and religion , and freedom of expression (speech). The Human Rights Act 1998 incorporated the European Convention on Human Rights into UK law.  The government, public bodies and the courts must follow the principles of the Convention.

Question: What is the name of the 24-hour helpline for domestic violence victims?
Explanation: It is important for anyone facing domestic violence to get help as soon as possible. A solicitor or the Citizens Advice Bureau can explain the available options. Question: When were Forced Marriage Protection Orders introduced in England, Wales and Northern Ireland?
Explanation: Forced Marriage Protection Orders were introduced in 2008 for England, Wales and Northern Ireland under the Forced Marriage (Civil Protection) Act 2007. Court orders can be obtained to protect a person from being forced into a marriage, or to protect a person in a forced marriage. Similar Protection Orders were introduced in Scotland in November 2011. A potential victim, or someone acting for them, can apply for an order. Anyone found to have breached an order can be jailed for up to two years for contempt of court.

Question: What is the second-largest party in the House of Commons called?
Explanation: The second-largest party in the House of Commons is called the opposition. The leader of the opposition usually becomes Prime Minister if his or her party wins the next General Election. The leader of the opposition leads his or her party in pointing out what they see as the government’s failures and weaknesses. One important opportunity to do this is at Prime Minister’s Questions, which takes place every week while Parliament is sitting. The leader of the opposition also appoints senior opposition MPs to be ‘shadow ministers’. They form the shadow cabinet and their role is to challenge the government and put forward alternative policies.

Question: To whom are civil servants accountable?
Explanation: Civil servants support the government in developing and implementing its policies. They also deliver public services. Civil servants are accountable to ministers. Question: Who is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth?
Explanation: The Commonwealth is an association of countries that support each other and work together towards shared goals in democracy and development. Most member states were once part of the British Empire, although a few countries which were not have also joined. The monarch (currently King Charles III) is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth, which currently has 56 member states. Membership is voluntary. The Commonwealth has no power over its members, although it can suspend membership. The Commonwealth is based on the core values of democracy, good government and the rule of law.

Question: What was the original name of the European Union?
Explanation: The European Union (EU), originally called the European Economic Community (EEC), was set up by six western European countries (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands) who signed the Treaty of Rome on 25 March 1957. Question: What is the term for persuading people to vote for a candidate by knocking on doors or handing out leaflets?
Explanation: Political parties welcome new members. Joining one is a way to demonstrate your support for certain views and to get involved in the democratic process. Political parties are particularly busy at election times. Members work hard to persuade people to vote for their candidates – for instance, by handing out leaflets in the street or by knocking on people’s doors and asking for their support. This is called ‘canvassing’. You don’t have to tell a canvasser how you intend to vote if you don’t want to.

Question: Who can stand for Office as a local councillor in the UK?
Explanation: British citizens can stand for Office as a local councillor, a member of Parliament (or the devolved equivalents) or a member of the European Parliament. This is an opportunity to become even more involved in the political life of the UK. You may also be able to stand for Office if you are an Irish citizen, an eligible Commonwealth citizen or (except for standing to be an MP) a citizen of another EU country. You can find out more about joining a political party from the individual party websites.

Question: What is an important action to take regarding waste?
Explanation: It is important to recycle as much of your waste as you can. Using recycled materials to make new products uses less energy and means that we do not need to extract more raw materials from the earth. It also means that less rubbish is created, so the amount being put into landfill is reduced. A good way to support your local community is to shop for products locally where you can. This will help businesses and farmers in your area and in Britain. It will also reduce your carbon footprint, because the products you buy will not have had to travel as far. Walking and using public transport to get around when you can is also a good way to protect the environment. It means that you create less pollution than when you use a car.
